questions.question: 1. In a linear-probing hash table, which of the following circumstances results in linear running time for a random search hit?

answers.a: All keys hash to same index
answers.b: All keys hash to different indices
answers.c: All keys hash to an even-numbered index
answers.d: All keys hash to different even-numbered indices

explanations.a: If all keys hash to the same location, finding the i-th inserted key will require I lookups. Since the i-th key is random, the probability of looking it up is 1/n.
explanations.b: If all keys hash to different locations, the inserted key can be found in constant time.
explanations.c: If all keys hash to an even-numbered index, we can't say about the running time as they can all be mapped to the same index or different even-numbered indexes.
explanations.d: If all keys hash to different locations, the inserted key can be found in constant time.

questions.question: 2. In a hash table, what is the ideal definition of a collision?

answers.a: Two entries are identical except for their keys
answers.b: Two entries with different data have the exact same key
answers.c: Two entries with different keys have the same exact hash value
answers.d: Two entries with the exact same key have different hash values

questions.question: 3. Which of the following statement(s) is TRUE?

answers.a: A hash function takes a message of arbitrary length and generates a fixed length code.
answers.b: A hash function takes a message of fixed length and generates a code of variable length.
